Definition: Resources that are accessible to all members of a community, such as natural resources, cultural heritage, and public spaces, managed collectively.
Goods that are non-excludable and non-rivalrous, meaning they are available to everyone and one personâ€™s use does not reduce availability to others, such as clean air and public parks.
Information and knowledge resources that are collectively created and maintained online and freely accessible to all, such as open-source software and wikis.
The ability to maintain or improve the quality and availability of resources over the long term without harming the environment or depleting the resources.
The action of working with others to achieve a common goal, especially in the context of sharing resources and knowledge.
The introduction of new ideas, products, or methods, which can drive progress and improvement within the commons.
Assets that are used jointly by a group of people or organizations, reducing duplication and increasing efficiency.
The practice of providing unrestricted access to information, research, and resources, allowing anyone to use and share them freely.
A governance approach where a group collaboratively makes decisions and manages resources, ensuring fair and equitable use.
The principle of fairness and justice in the distribution of resources and opportunities, ensuring that everyone has access to what they need to thrive.
The practice of being open and clear about processes, decisions, and data, which builds trust and accountability within the community.
Individuals or groups who have an interest or stake in a particular resource, project, or outcome, including community members, organizations, and governments.
The capacity of a system or community to adapt to changes and recover from disruptions, ensuring long-term stability and sustainability.
The process of creating and strengthening relationships among members of a community, fostering a sense of belonging and mutual support.
The practice of exchanging information, skills, and expertise among individuals or groups to enhance collective understanding and capabilities.
The frameworks and processes through which decisions are made and resources are managed, including rules, policies, and organizational structures.
The principle of using resources and technologies in a way that is morally right and respects the rights and dignity of individuals.
The protection of data from unauthorized access, corruption, or theft, ensuring its confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
The practice of ensuring that all individuals and groups, especially those who are marginalized, have the opportunity to participate and benefit equally.
Development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs, integrating economic, social, and environmental considerations.

A model of socio-economic production in which the creative energy of large numbers of people is coordinated (usually with the aid of the internet) into large, meaningful projects mostly without traditional hierarchical organization.
Software for which the original source code is made freely available and may be redistributed and modified.
The practice of obtaining input or services by soliciting contributions from a large group of people, typically via the internet.
The distribution of functions, powers, people, or things away from a central location or authority.
Development that is driven by the people who are most affected by it, ensuring that their needs and preferences are prioritized.
Individual and collective actions designed to identify and address issues of public concern.
A process where citizens or stakeholders have the power to contribute to decision-making processes.
Data that is freely available to everyone to use and republish as they wish, without restrictions.
Shared resources in the form of information, ideas, and data that are created and maintained collectively.
Ensuring that all individuals and communities have the information technology capacity needed for full participation in society.
A model that encourages organizations to use external ideas and innovations in conjunction with internal ones.
The sustained ability of a community to withstand and recover from adversity.
Activities or policies that support the creation, management, and defense of commons.
The networks of relationships among people who live and work in a particular society, enabling that society to function effectively.
Licensing schemes that allow content creators to grant the public permission to use their work under certain conditions.
A systematic process for continually improving management policies and practices by learning from the outcomes of previously employed policies and practices.
Systems and rules for managing commons, typically involving community control and stewardship.
Creative works to which no exclusive intellectual property rights apply.
Combining resources from multiple sources for the benefit of all contributors.
A system of governance using consent-based decision-making among equivalent individuals and an organizational structure based on cybernetic principles.
The practice of creating web applications and services using open standards, open-source software, and open data, promoting accessibility, interoperability, and collaboration.

A flexible form of governance that allows participants to delegate their voting power to trusted representatives, who can then vote on their behalf, combining elements of direct and representative democracy.
A movement or approach that promotes transparency, participation, and collaboration in government and civic processes, often leveraging technology to engage citizens more effectively.
An economic system aimed at eliminating waste and the continual use of resources, focusing on recycling, reusing, and regenerating materials in a closed-loop system.

Organizational structures or frameworks that determine how resources, responsibilities, and decision-making powers are distributed among stakeholders, often designed to ensure fairness and accountability.
Goods that become more valuable as more people use them, such as social networks and communication platforms, benefiting from network effects where increased usage enhances the overall value.
The ability of different systems, platforms, and applications to work together seamlessly.
A set of protocols and tools for building software and applications, allowing different systems to communicate with each other.
Guidelines and specifications set by organizations like the W3C to ensure the long-term growth of the web.
An approach to web development that ensures websites function well on a variety of devices and screen sizes.
The practice of making websites and web applications usable by people of all abilities and disabilities.
A form of democracy in which people decide on policy initiatives directly.
A type of democracy where elected officials represent a group of people in decision-making.
A system where individuals can delegate their voting power to another person or representative.
A group decision-making process that seeks the consent of all participants.
A decentralized and distributed digital ledger used to record transactions across many computers.
Technology used to empower citizens or make government processes more efficient and transparent.
A democratic process in which community members decide how to allocate part of a public budget.
The use of digital tools and systems to provide public services and engage with citizens.
Online tools that facilitate citizen participation in civic processes.
Programs and practices aimed at making government operations open and accessible to the public.
Designing products with consideration for the environmental impact throughout their lifecycle.
The process of transforming by-products, waste materials, or unwanted products into new materials or products of better quality.
A sustainable business strategy that mimics the regenerative cycle of nature in which waste is reused.
Using resources in a way that maximizes their value while minimizing environmental impact.
A philosophy that encourages the redesign of resource life cycles so that all products are reused.
The process of involving individuals, groups, or organizations that may be affected by or can affect a decision or action.
A structure that outlines the rules, practices, and processes used to direct and manage an organization.
A percentage of ownership in a company or project, representing a claim on its assets and earnings.
Tools and processes used to hold individuals or organizations responsible for their actions and decisions.
A governance arrangement where stakeholders actively share decision-making power.
The phenomenon where a product or service gains additional value as more people use it.
The principle that the value of a network is proportional to the square of the number of its users.
An economic and social activity facilitated by platforms, typically digital, which connect buyers, sellers, and users.
A complex network of interconnected digital technologies, services, and users.
A platform that brings together two distinct but interdependent groups of customers, such as buyers and sellers.
